translated: The Lesser Goose Jātaka
“Sumukha, the birds are flying away, not gathering;
Go, you too, don’t hesitate,
there is no friendship with the bound.”

analyzed: gacche vā aham na vā gacche
translated: “Whether I go or not,
I will not become immortal because of that.

original: Sukhitaṁ taṁ upāsitvā,🔽dukkhitaṁ taṁ kathaṁ jahe.
analyzed: sukhitam tam upāsitvā  dukkhitam tam katham jahe
translated: Having served you in happiness,🔽how can I abandon you in suffering?
Death with you,
or life without you;
That very death is better,
than living without you.

original: Nesa dhammo mahārāja,🔽yaṁ taṁ evaṁ gataṁ jahe;
analyzed: na isa dhammaḥ mahā rāja  yam tam evam gatam jahe
translated: This is not the way, great king,🔽that you should abandon me who has gone thus;
Whatever your fate, lord of birds,
that is agreeable to me.”
“What is the fate of one bound by a snare,

analyzed: gati aññā mahānasā  sā katham cetayānassa
translated: other than great suffering?🔽How can that be agreeable to you,

original: muttassa tava ruccati.🔽Kaṁ vā tvaṁ passase atthaṁ,
analyzed: muttassa tava ruccati  kam vā tvam passase attha
translated: when you are free to think?🔽What benefit do you see for me,🔽and for you, bird,
or for the remaining relatives,
when the destruction of both our lives is imminent?
That which is not given to anyone,
gone in the darkness of blindness;
A life that is accumulated in such a way,
What is the purpose for which you have come?”
“How is it, best of fliers,
that you do not understand the meaning of the Dhamma?
The Dhamma, when fully understood,
shows the meaning to living beings.
So I, looking to the Dhamma,
the meaning that has arisen from the Dhamma,
and seeing your devotion to me,
I do not doubt my life.
Surely this is the true Dhamma,
that a friend should help a friend;
I will not abandon you for the sake of my life,
remembering the law of cause and effect.”

analyzed: su ayam dhammaḥ ca te ciṇṇaḥ
translated: “This Dhamma has been practiced by you,
and your devotion to me is known.
Do what you want with me,
go, I am pleased with you.
But if you go at this time,
the piece of meat that I have from my relatives
will be fully understood by you,
and it will be completely covered.”
Thus as they were consulting,
the noble ones of noble conduct,
a hunter appeared to them,
like a disease to the sick.
He considered the two birds,
for the sake of their long-term welfare;
Both sat in silence,
not moving from their seats.
And seeing Dhataraṭṭha,
they rose up from all sides.
“Go forward quickly,
bird-enemy, against the king of birds.”
And he, going forward quickly,
attacked the supreme bird;🔽The fowler thought, “They are bound,”
while the other one was thinking, “I am bound.”
One was sitting as if bound,
and the other one was not bound.
Having attacked the one sitting as if bound,
he looked on with fear.
Then he, as if in doubt,🔽addressed the white one,
the one sitting with his body extended,
the leader of the flock of birds.
“Since one bound with a great snare

original: baddho na kurute disaṁ;🔽Atha kasmā abaddho tvaṁ,
analyzed: baddhaḥ na kurute disa  atha kasmai abaddhaḥ tva
translated: does not move in any direction,🔽why is it that you, powerful bird,
do not fly away, though unbound?
What is this bird to you,
that you, though free, attend on the bound?
The birds fly away,
why do you alone stay behind?”
“He is my friend, my bird-friend,
he is my life-companion;
I will not abandon him,
until the time comes for me to go.”
“But how is it that this bird
did not see the snare stretched out?
This is the way of the great ones,
I’m not able to understand this misfortune.”
“When a pet is defeated,

translated: and then your life comes to an end.”🔽“Is this not a pleasant companionship?

analyzed: na ca iva me tvam baddhaḥ asi
translated: “I’m not bound to you,

Go quickly as you wish,

analyzed: jīva tvam anighaḥ cira  na iva aham etam icchāmi
translated: and live a long life free from danger.”
“I don’t want to take the life of another.
If you’re satisfied with one,
release this one and eat him.
We’re the same in height and build,
and we’re the same in age.
You don’t live by his profit,
but by your own.
So look on,
and let your hunger be satisfied.
First bind me with the net,
and then release the king of the birds.
That’s your profit,
and you have asked for it,
Friendship with the Dhataraṭṭhas,
can be yours for life.”

analyzed: passantu naḥ mahā saṅghā  tayā muttam itas gata
translated: “May the great Saṅgha see🔽you released from here,
your friends, companions, relatives,
sons, wives, and kinsmen.
There are not many like you
here who are friends
like you are to Dhataraṭṭha,

I release your friend,
let the king be your follower;
Go quickly from here

“Pleased and released,
respectful to his benefactor,

analyzed: ajjhabhāsatha vakkaṅgo  vācam kaṇṇa sukham bhaṇa
translated: Vakkaṅga spoke aloud,🔽speaking words pleasing to the ear:
“Thus, hunter, rejoice

“Come, I will instruct you,

Having quickly brought him to the city,
show us both to the king;
“They are not bound, they are in their natural state,
in a cage, standing on both sides.

analyzed: dhataraṭṭhāḥ mahā rāja  hasa adhipatinaḥ ime
translated: These are the great kings Dhataraṭṭha,🔽the lords of the geese;
This one is the king of the geese,

analyzed: asasayam imam disvā  hasa rājam narādhipo
translated: Without a doubt, seeing this king of geese,
the lord of men will be pleased, delighted,

Having heard his words,
he brought them to the king.
Quickly going to the city,
he showed the geese to the king;
“They are not bound, they are in their natural state,
in a cage, standing on both sides.
“These are the great kings Dhataraṭṭha,
the lords of the geese;
This one is the king of the geese,
this one is the second in command.”
“But how did these birds come
into your hands?
How did the hunter, O great king,
come to have these lords here?”
“Nets were spread in the marshes,
O lord of men,
in whatever place I thought
would be a hindrance to the birds.

analyzed: tādisam pāsam āsajja  hasa rājā abajjhatha
translated: Having set such a net,🔽the king of geese fell into it;
not bound, he stood there,
You spoke to me.
Very difficult for the unrighteous,

Having given up his own life,
worthy of life,

Having heard his words,

Then I released the bird,

analyzed: anuññāsim sukhena ca  saḥ patītaḥ pamuttena
translated: and I gave him permission with pleasure.🔽The bird, having been released,
grateful to the king,
Vakkaṅga spoke to him,
speaking words pleasing to the ear.
‘Rejoice thus, hunter,
together with all your relatives;
Just as I rejoice today,
having seen the bird-king released.
Come, I will instruct you,
so that you too will obtain;
This Dhataraṭṭha will gain,
he will not see any evil.
Having quickly taken you to the city,
show us both to the king;
Unbound, being as you are,
standing in a cage on both sides.
“Dhataraṭṭha, great king,
These are the leaders of the geese;
This one is the king of the geese,
and this one is the general.”
“Without a doubt, seeing this,
the king of men will be pleased;
He will be delighted and generous,
and will give you much wealth.”
Thus, by his words,
I brought both of them here.
For it was here that both of them
were approved by me.
But this bird has gone away,
the one with the highest Dhamma.
For a hunter like me,
you should arouse tenderness.
And for your sake, O King,
I see no other like it;
In the whole village of hunters,
look at it, O King of men!”
Seeing the king sitting
on a beautiful golden seat,
Vakkaṅga spoke out,
speaking words pleasing to the ear:
“Are you well, sir?
Are you free from illness?
Is this kingdom prosperous,
do you rule righteously?”
“I am well, O goose,
and I am free from illness.
And this kingdom is prosperous,
I rule righteously.”
“Is there any fault found with your ministers,
or is there any doubt about their lives?
Or is there any doubt about their lives
in regard to your affairs?”
“There is no fault found with my ministers,
nor is there any doubt about their lives.
Nor is there any doubt about their lives
in regard to my affairs.”
“Is there a wife who is your equal,
who is obedient and speaks pleasantly;
Who is endowed with beauty, youth and wealth,
who follows your wishes?”
“There is a wife who is my equal,
who is obedient and speaks pleasantly;
Who is endowed with beauty, youth and wealth,

“Have you, by chance, fallen into the trap,

“You are safe, Great King,

analyzed: tadā ayam su mukhaḥ yā iva
translated: Therefore this Sumukha
the wise one replied.
Having heard his words,
I was filled with confidence;
Then Pāmucī released me,
and I was allowed to go in peace.
And this was thought of by Sumukha,
for this purpose:
‘Going to the presence of the Lord,

“Welcome indeed is this to me,
I am satisfied with the sight;
And he will receive much wealth,
as much as he desires.”
Having satisfied the hunter,
with wealth the Lord of Men;
he spoke to Vakkaṅga,
speaking words that were pleasing to the ear.
“Whatever is subject to the Dhamma,
whatever is under my control;
All sovereignty is yours,
be confident and take what you wish.

analyzed: dāna attham upabhottum vā  yam caññam upakappati
translated: For the sake of giving or for enjoyment,🔽whatever else is of use;
I give you this wealth,
I relinquish my sovereignty to you.”
“Just as this Sumukha,
the wise one spoke to me;
He is my dearest friend,
the one who is endowed with wisdom.”
“I, great king,
am the enemy of the king of nāgas;
I am not able to turn back,
it would not be my discipline.
He is the best of us,
and you are the best of beings;
The lord of the earth, the lord of men,
is worshipped for many reasons.
While they were speaking thus,🔽the case being investigated,
the messenger should turn back,
between the two, lord of men.”
“The hunter, it seems, is righteous,
the wise one, born from an egg;
For one who has not done (wrong),
the way would not be like this.
Thus he is the best of us,
thus he is the best of beings;
As far as I have seen,
I do not see anyone like him.
I am satisfied with you naturally,
and with your sweet speech;
And this is my wish,
that you two would see each other for a long time.”
“Whatever should be done by supreme friends,
that has been done by you to us;
We have certainly attained you,
and you have attained us.
Surely it is a great loss
to the assembly of our relatives;
Through not seeing us,
and suffering among many birds.
For the sake of dispelling their grief,
we have been permitted by you;
